Is supabase good for managing oauth on ios or should i go with firebase?
description:
i’m building an ios app on swift and only want to offer oauth for the mvp. ive used supabase for all my webapps and love it alot but never used it for ios. curious, how has your experience been? is it relatively straightforward for ios as well or should i just sell my soul and go with firebase?

advice is suuuper appreciated

advice is suuuper appreciated

Reflection and open implementations (2006)
description: We review the state-of-the-art of reflection and metaprogramming, prior to our work on partial behavioral reflection and Reflex, and open implementations. The first four sections are dedicated to reflection. Section 1 introduces the concept of reflection and its application to programming languages. Section 2 discusses reflection in the particular context of object-oriented programming languages. Then, since we are interested in addressing issues in the concrete applicability of reflection, we dedicate Section 3 to the structuring and engineering of metalevel architectures, while implementation considerations are dealt with in Section 4. After this comprehensive review of reflection, the last section discusses the related area of open implementations (Section 5).
description_plain: We review the state-of-the-art of reflection and metaprogramming, prior to our work on partial behavioral reflection and Reflex, and open implementations. The first four sections are dedicated to reflection. Section 1 introduces the concept of reflection and its application to programming languages. Section 2 discusses reflection in the particular context of object-oriented programming languages. Then, since we are interested in addressing issues in the concrete applicability of reflection, we dedicate Section 3 to the structuring and engineering of metalevel architectures, while implementation considerations are dealt with in Section 4. After this comprehensive review of reflection, the last section discusses the related area of open implementations (Section 5).

Cosmoe: BeOS Class Library on top of Wayland
description:
I don’t know if anyone remembers it, but way back there was a project called Cosmoe, which aimed to provide an implementation of the Haiku application environment on top of the Linux kernel. Turns out the author started working on it again.

The “new” flavour is slightly less ambitious – it doesn’t include the app_server and the registrar, it’s “just” a port of the BeOS class libraries on top of Linux and Wayland. The full port (now called Cosmoe Classic) also got some updates.

Both are pretty cool hacks. The new flavour is a pretty interesting example of how to (re-)implement an old-style UI library with contemporary tooling – though technically, it helps that Cairo is still contemporary tooling, I guess. The classic flavour is an even more interesting exercise in porting a bunch of non-Linux functionality.

Tagging this retrocomputing since we don’t have a UI tag and I think BeOS qualifies as retrocomputing at this point :-). osdev seemed like a bit of a reach – the classic flavour is kind of there, I guess, but not quite the author’s main focus.
description_plain:
I don't know if anyone remembers it, but way back there was a project called Cosmoe, which aimed to provide an implementation of the Haiku application environment on top of the Linux kernel. Turns out the author started working on it again.

The ["new" flavour](https://gitlab.com/haydentech/cosmoe-wayland) is slightly less ambitious -- it doesn't include the app_server and the registrar, it's "just" a port of the BeOS class libraries on top of Linux and Wayland. The full port (now called Cosmoe Classic) also [got some updates](https://gitlab.com/haydentech/cosmoe-haiku/).

Both are pretty cool hacks. The new flavour is a pretty interesting example of how to (re-)implement an old-style UI library with contemporary tooling -- though technically, it helps that Cairo is still contemporary tooling, I guess. The classic flavour is an even more interesting exercise in porting a bunch of non-Linux functionality.

Tagging this `retrocomputing` since we don't have a UI tag and I think BeOS qualifies as retrocomputing at this point :-). `osdev` seemed like a bit of a reach -- the classic flavour is kind of there, I guess, but not quite the author's main focus.
